title: Why high stamp duty and unaffordable house prices have created the 'stay put generation'
text:
For most of this year, Nathan Aylott has lived on a building site – by choice. The architect has been taking his work home with him, spending evenings and weekends renovating his Victorian house in Windsor. “We have done a loft conversion and extended into the side return,” says Aylott, 39. “Now, we basically have a new property inside an old one.”

Although he has kept costs down by doing as much of the work himself as possible – from sanding floors to fitting doors – Aylott, the co-founder of interior design and brand studio Aylott + Van Tromp, and his wife have spent about £100,000 doing up the house they bought for £490,000 at the end of 2017. They raised the cash for the revamp by remortgaging,...
description: For most of this year, Nathan Aylott has lived on a building site – by choice.
